overview.short: Leuconostoc lactis is a heterofermentative lactic acid bacterium, typically a catalase-negative, non-motile Gram-positive coccus/coccobacillus associated with dairy and fermented foods.
overview.clinical_context: Primarily food-associated but can rarely be implicated in opportunistic infections, particularly in immunocompromised hosts.

species_markers.notes: Supports dairy-associated Leuconostoc such as L. lactis when combined with LAB morphology and catalase negativity.
Consistent with heterofermentative lactic acid bacteria.
Helps separate from Enterococcus in mixed-differential workflows.

common_confusions.reason: Overlapping heterofermentative LAB profile; differentiation often requires extended carbohydrate panels or MALDI-TOF.
Catalase-negative Gram-positive cocci in clinical samples; enterococci often show stronger salt tolerance and bile-esculin positivity.

when_to_question_identification: No gas production with otherwise similar phenotype may suggest Streptococcus or Enterococcus rather than Leuconostoc.
A strongly beta-haemolytic pattern suggests alternative genera.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Useful for distinguishing L. lactis from closely related Leuconostoc species.
Rapid, reliable species-level identification among lactic acid bacteria.
Intrinsic resistance supports Leuconostoc genus suspicion in clinical contexts.
